lorebooks.name: Ashen Gods
lorebooks.description: Ashen Gods is a manga/anime series created by Shiro Takezawa.
lorebooks.creator: Haneylooker

1.content:
Chapter 1: The Fire That Burns
Opening Scene: The world is establishedâ€” 57 gods rule over humanity as cruel tyrants, worshipped despite their oppression.
Kael, a 16-year-old orphan, lives in a small village called Vaelith that fears and rever toes the gods.
The annual Tribute Ceremony is taking place, where Jax, God of Minor Quakes demands a human sacrifice.
A little girl who is homeless is chosen. Kael protests, enraging Jax.
Jax strikes Kael down, but instead of dying, something awakens inside himâ€”the Ashen Mark ignites for the first time.

Chapter 2: First Blood
Overwhelmed by pain and confusion, Kaelâ€™s body moves on instinct, resisting the divine power.
Jax, intrigued and enraged, decides to kill Kael personally.
Kaelâ€™s first fight is brutalâ€”he has no experience, no weapons, and is completely outmatched.
A mysterious warrior intervenes (Theros Nightvale), helping Kael survive by easily killing Jax but forcing him to flee the village forever.
The village declares Kael an enemy of the gods, placing a âš·3,000,000 bounty on his head.

Chapter 3: The Hunt Begins
Kael is now a fugitive, marked by the gods. Bounty hunters and inquisitors are already searching for him.
He struggles to understand why he survivedâ€”his Ashen Mark still burns, and he starts experiencing strange visions or sensations.
The first bounty hunter appears(Varian Voss)â€”Kael has his first real battle against a skilled human opponent.
Though completely outclassed, Kael wins through luck and raw desperation, but realizes he needs real training.
He sets off in search of someone who can teach him how to survive.

Chapter 4: The Mentorâ€™s Test
Kael tracks down the warrior that saved him (Theros Nightvale), a godslayer who fights against the divine and the only other human with the Ashen Mark.
Theros wants nothing to do with Kael, warning him that fighting gods isn't worth the suffering and that a boy like him isn't built for that life.
Kael refuses to give up, insisting that he needs to learn how to fight.
Theros gives Kael a harsh, near-impossible testâ€”survive a night in a dangerous territory without weapons.
Kael barely survives, relying on instinct and his slowly developing Ashen Mark.
Impressed, Theros reluctantly agrees to train himâ€”but only for a short time.

Chapter 5: The Markâ€™s First Evolution
Training begins. The mentor teaches Kael about the weaknesses of divine beings and how to exploit them.
Kael strugglesâ€”he is still human, still weak. But his rage and drive push him forward.
The Ashen Mark reacts, showing its first evolutionâ€”Kael gains the ability to resist divine attacks more effectively.
However, the mark also attracts attentionâ€”a god senses rebellion awakening and sends an execution squad to kill Kael.
The chapter ends with Kael and Theros facing off against the attackers.

Chapter 6: Baptism by Fire
A squad of elite inquisitors and demigod warriors, including High Inquisitor Daziel arrives.
Kael gets his first real taste of combat against divine-powered opponents.
His mentor takes out most enemies, but Kael is forced to fight one-on-one against a lesser demigod.
Though heavily injured, he kills his first divine being, and the Ashen Mark grows stronger.



Chapter 7: Wanted Dead or Alive
News of Kaelâ€™s first kill spreads fastâ€”his bounty skyrockets to âš·50,000,000.
Kael and Theros go into hiding, but hunters and mercenaries are closing in.
Kael learns about legendary god-slaying weaponsâ€”items forged to kill gods.
They set off toward a ruined temple said to hold a weapon capable of slaying a god permanently.
The chapter ends with them arriving at the temple, sensing something far worse than bounty hunters inside.

Chapter 8: Trial of the Forgotten Weapon
The temple is filled with traps, curses, and divine remnants.
Kael experiences visions of past god-slayers, learning more about those who came before him.
The weaponâ€”Ebonfang â€“ The Blade That Drinks Divinityâ€”is sealed behind a trial of worth.
Kael must prove himself, not through raw strength, but through sheer determination and willpower.
He faces a spirit guardian that challenges his resolve:

 â€œYou are still weak. Do you truly believe you can kill a god?â€



Kael barely survives the trial, emerging with his first true god-slaying weapon.

Chapter 9: A God Descends
Just as Kael obtains the weapon, a high-ranking god named Therion, God of Beasts and Wilderness descends upon the templeâ€”the first true divine being he has ever encountered.
This god has come not just to kill Kael, but to erase him completely.
Theros tells Kael to runâ€”this is not a fight he can win.
Kael refuses. For the first time, he faces a full-fledged god with nothing but his will and a weapon made to kill their kind.
The chapter ends with Kael charging forward, weapon in hand, as the god prepares to strike.

Chapter 10: Against the Divine
Kael vs. His First True God, Therion â€“ an impossible battle.


Therion underestimates Kael at first, toying with him.


But Kael, through sheer rage, strategy, and the power of his evolving Ashen Mark, lands a critical blow, wounding the god.


The god, enraged, stops holding back, and Kael is brutally overwhelmed.


Just as the god is about to kill him, Theron comes in to save Kael, killing Therion in an intense, epic battle.


The battle ends with Kael severely injured, and Therosâ€™ bounty going up to âš·18,750,978,645,000.


Theros gets Kael to shelter and tells him he'll take him to meet people that will help them defeat the Gods




Chapter 11: Welcome to the Rebellion of Sinners

Kael awakens in an underground sanctuary, heavily bandaged, his body still aching from his battle with Therion.

Theros introduces him to the Rebels of Sin, a faction that opposes the gods.

The rebellion is led by Erian Starweaver, a former priest who lost faith in the gods and now fights against their tyranny.

Other key members include:

Elwynn Nightshade â€“ A powerful witch and one of their best strategists.

Cassius Darkhaven â€“ A heretic and assassin, skilled in eliminating inquisitors.

Kaelith Sunshadow â€“ A warrior who was once a Seraphim Knight, now wielding a god-forged spear.

Arin Vexis â€“ The rebellionâ€™s tactician and spy.

Grimbold Ironfist â€“ The blacksmith responsible for forging weapons that can harm divine beings.

Lyra Flynn & Caius Nightwalker â€“ Two young orphans who survived a massacre by the gods.

Mira Blackwood & Thrain Hammerstrike â€“ Veteran fighters who have been resisting the gods for years.


Kael is skeptical at first but sees that these people have suffered under the gods just like he has.

The rebels view Kael as a potential savior, but not all trust him yet. His bounty makes him a liability, and some question whether heâ€™s strong enough to be the â€œGodslayer.â€

Theros warns Kael that the rebellion is valuable, but trusting them blindly is dangerousâ€”betrayal is always a possibility.

The chapter ends with Erian offering Kael a choice: Join us, and we will teach you how to bring the gods to their kneesâ€¦ or walk away, and fight alone.



---

Chapter 12: Baptism in Blood

Kael chooses to join the rebellion, but they do not accept him fully yet. He must prove himself.

His first mission: infiltrate a Divine Order stronghold and assassinate a high-ranking inquisitor.

Cassius Darkhaven and Arin Vexis accompany him, testing his ability to operate in enemy territory.

The stronghold is heavily fortified, filled with Seraphim Knights.

Kael sneaks in but is caught, leading to an intense battle.

He barely manages to complete the mission, but in doing so, he exposes his Ashen Mark, alarming the Divine Order.

High Inquisitor Daziel receives word of Kaelâ€™s involvement, marking him as a personal enemy.

The chapter ends with Kael returning to the rebellion, bloodied but victoriousâ€”his baptism in blood is complete.



---

Chapter 13: The Ember of War (Introduction of Lexa Vael)

The rebellion intercepts news that Dravon, God of Bloodshed and Conquest, is preparing to lead a raid against a village suspected of harboring heretics.

The rebels plan an ambush, hoping to weaken the Divine Orderâ€™s grip.

During the battle, Kael encounters Lexa Vael, a demi-god daughter of Dravon.

Lexa is leading a squad of Seraphim Knights, but she is different from the othersâ€”she questions the gods' actions.

Kael and Lexa engage in a brutal fight, but neither is able to finish the other off.

Before Kael can strike a fatal blow, Dravon himself appears, forcing the rebels to retreat.

Lexa watches as her father slaughters innocents without hesitation, planting seeds of doubt within her.

The chapter ends with Lexa looking at her bloodied hands, questioning everything she has believed in.



---

Chapter 14: A Price on His Head

Kaelâ€™s bounty is now at âš·150,000,000, and bounty hunters are swarming.

The Divine Order tightens its grip, forcing the rebels into hiding.

Kael realizes that every battle makes him stronger, but also brings more suffering to those around him.

He begins questioning whether he is truly the savior they needâ€”or just another killer.



---

Chapter 15: The Hunterâ€™s Moon

Kael crosses paths with Varian Voss again, the bounty hunter who once tried to kill him.

However, instead of fighting, Varian offers a proposition: â€œWe have a common enemy. Letâ€™s not waste time killing each other.â€

Varian provides information on Vaelith, the Moon Weaver, a goddess who thrives on deception and illusions.

He claims she is orchestrating events behind the scenes, manipulating both humans and gods alike.

The chapter ends with Kael considering an uneasy alliance with his former enemy.





Chapter 16: Shadows of the Oracle (Introduction of Eris Gravesong)

The rebellion seeks out Eris Gravesong, a former Oracle of Vaelith who turned against the gods.

Eris is a tragic figureâ€”cursed with visions of the future, but unable to change fate.

She warns Kael: â€œYou will bathe in the blood of gods, but the price will be unbearable.â€

Eris tells Kael about the Prophecy of the Ashen Mark, foretelling the rise of a mortal who will end the reign of the gods.

The chapter ends with Kael asking, â€œAnd what happens after?â€

Eris simply replies, â€œEven I do not know.â€

â€”

Chapter 17: A Song of Betrayal

Kael and the Rebels launch a raid on a Divine Order stronghold, aiming to free captured sympathizers.

During the mission, Eris's powers as an oracle manifest, allowing her to foresee an ambushâ€”but she hides the full truth from Kael.

The raid turns into a bloodbath as a group of Seraphim Knights led by High Inquisitor Daziel arrives, turning the tide against them.

Kael barely escapes with Eris, but many Rebels are slaughtered. The survivors blame Eris for not warning them completely.

Eris reveals her vision: if she had interfered fully, Kael would have died instead.

The chapter ends with tensions rising within the rebellionâ€”can Eris truly be trusted?



---

Chapter 18: Ghosts of the Past

After the failed raid, Kael and Theros travel to a ruined monastery, where the first Godslayers once trained.

Inside, Kael discovers ancient inscriptions about the Ashen Mark, revealing that it adapts with each divine being slain.

He experiences a vision of a past Godslayerâ€”Theros Nightvaleâ€™s ancestor, who attempted to end the gods but was betrayed.

Meanwhile, High Inquisitor Daziel continues his hunt, placing an even higher bounty on Kael.

The chapter ends with Kael unlocking a new stage of his Ashen Mark, granting him limited resistance to divine regeneration.



---

Chapter 19: The Chains of a Demi-God

Lexa Vael, the daughter of Dravon, struggles with her identity as a demi-god. Raised by the Divine Order, sheâ€™s a warrior caught between two worlds.

Ordered to track down Kael, she questions her loyalty after seeing the gods' cruelty firsthand.

Meanwhile, Kael is forced into a brutal battle against an elite inquisitor, barely managing to survive.

Lexa, secretly watching, chooses not to intervene but begins to question her purpose.

The chapter ends with Lexa standing at a crossroads, unsure of whether to remain loyal to her father or help Kael.



---

Chapter 20: Shadows and Ash

The Rebels plan to assassinate a lesser god during a grand festival, hoping to prove that deicide is possible.

Eris warns Kael that something feels wrong, but he refuses to back down.

The mission is a disasterâ€”the god was expecting them, and the Divine Order retaliates with full force.

Kael faces off against the lesser god, struggling even with Ebonfang.

Just when all seems lost, Lexa Vael arrives, saving Kael.

The chapter ends with Kael and Lexa escaping together, but now Lexa is branded a traitor.



---

Chapter 21: The Burning Oath

Lexa officially joins the Rebels, swearing to help Kael fight the gods.

Theros warns Kael not to trust her so easily, but Kael believes in her.

Lexa shares critical intel: The Nameless One has taken personal interest in Kael.

Meanwhile, Daziel executes a village suspected of aiding Kael, showing his brutality.

The Rebels begin plotting their biggest attack yetâ€”a direct strike against a major godâ€™s temple.



---

Chapter 22: The Temple of Wrath

The target is Pyros, God of Fire and Destruction, a sadistic deity known for burning entire cities.

The Rebels launch an assault on his temple, drawing out his divine forces.

Kael faces Pyros himself, struggling against the overwhelming flames.

In the heat of battle, Kaelâ€™s Ashen Mark evolves again, granting him partial immunity to divine fire.

Pyros underestimates Kael, and Kael lands a devastating strike, forcing Pyros to retreat.

The Rebels claim victory, proving a major god can be woundedâ€”but at great cost.



---

Chapter 23: Ashes and Aftermath

The attack makes Kael a symbol of rebellion across Ocilia, but it also draws more divine wrath.

The Divine Order responds by sending High Inquisitor Daziel himself to eliminate Kael.

Meanwhile, Kael struggles with the toll of battleâ€”his body is changing, and his humanity is slipping.

Theros warns Kael that the Ashen Mark feeds on battle and vengeance.

The chapter ends with Kael vowing to remain in control, but doubts linger.



---

Chapter 24: The Godhunterâ€™s Gambit

Kael learns of another god-slaying weapon, the Spear of Oblivion, hidden in a ruined vault.

The Rebels split upâ€”Kael, Lexa, and Eris seek the weapon while Theros holds off bounty hunters.

Along the way, Kael and Lexa grow closer, with Lexa revealing her doubts about being part-god.

Inside the vault, they face a deadly divine construct protecting the weapon.

Kael claims the Spear of Oblivion but he gives it to Lexa. Daziel ambushes them as they leave.



---

Chapter 25: Dazielâ€™s Wrath

Dazielâ€™s power is on an entirely different level than any enemy Kael has faced before.

He fights Kael, Lexa, and Eris at the same time, pushing them to their limits.

Kael barely manages to defend against Dazielâ€™s divine smithing techniques.

The battle ends with Kael and his group escaping, but Daziel swears this is not over.



---

Chapter 26: The Price of Power

Kael begins to feel the cost of his growing strengthâ€”his Ashen Mark demands battle, and itâ€™s affecting his mind.

He confesses to Lexa that he fears losing himself.

Meanwhile, Eris warns Kael that his fate is becoming darkerâ€”she has seen visions of a burning Ocilia, with Kael standing amid the ashes.

The Rebels prepare for the inevitable final battle against the Divine Order.



---

Chapter 27: The Reckoning Begins

The final confrontation between Kael and Daziel is setâ€”a battle for the future of Ocilia.

Kael and his allies storm a Divine Order fortress, forcing Daziel to face him in battle.

Daziel reveals his own divine enhancements, showing he is no ordinary human.

The battle is intenseâ€”Kael struggles against Dazielâ€™s overwhelming strength.

Just when Daziel is about to win, Kaelâ€™s Ashen Mark evolves one last time, unlocking his strongest ability yet: Divine Negation.



---

Chapter 28: The Fall of an Inquisitor

With his new power, Kael negates Dazielâ€™s divine abilities, evening the fight.

The battle rages through the fortress, collapsing entire sections.

Lexa and Eris try to hold off reinforcements as Kael and Daziel fight to the death.

In a desperate move, Kael lands a final, devastating strike, bringing Daziel to his knees.

But instead of killing him, Kael spares Daziel, proving he is not like the gods.

Daziel barely escapes, humiliated and broken.



---

Chapter 29: A Godâ€™s Warning

Daziel returns to the capital, forced to explain his failure to The Nameless One.

Thrakos is not pleased, but he does not kill Daziel. Instead, he gives him one last chance.

Thrakos issues a final warning:
"If Kael continues to be a threatâ€¦ I will deal with him personally."

Daziel leaves, determined to never lose again.



---

Chapter 30: The Road to War

Kael and the Rebels celebrate their victory, but Kael knows this war is far from over.

Theros warns him: "You wounded the Divine Order, but they will come back stronger."

Kael reflects on his journeyâ€”he is no longer the boy from Vaelith. He is a Godslayer.

The chapter ends with Kael looking toward the horizon, knowing that his greatest battle is yet to come.



---

Chapters 31-40: Fractured Alliances and Personal Growth

Chapter 31: The Illusion of Safety

After their latest battle against the Divine Order, Kael and the rebels find temporary refuge in the ruins of an abandoned temple. Lexa, still challenging Kael to push himself further, spars with him aggressively. Their fights grow more personalâ€”Kael refuses to strike her seriously, while Lexa accuses him of holding back due to his emotions. Meanwhile, Theros warns Kael that his inexperience will get him killed if he doesnâ€™t embrace his potential.

Chapter 32: The Orphans' Trial Begins

Arin, Lyra, and Caius embark on a mission to steal supplies from a heavily guarded Divine Order outpost. Arin, ever the strategist, devises a near-flawless plan, but his overconfidence leads to miscalculations. Lyra, more physically capable, doubts his leadership but follows. Caius, the youngest, is eager to prove himself. When their plan falls apart, they are forced to adapt on the fly, leading to tension within the group.

Chapter 33: The Godhunterâ€™s Decision

Varian Voss crosses paths with the rebels once again, hired by the Divine Order to eliminate them. However, during a confrontation with Kael, he hesitates, sensing a greater truth in Kaelâ€™s fight against the gods. He withdraws but doesnâ€™t yet pledge allegiance. His internal struggle begins.

Chapter 34: Thrakos' Judgment

A high priest lies to Thrakos about a failed campaign against the rebels. Before he can finish his excuse, Thrakos crushes his skull with his fingers, smiling as he does so. Later, he addresses a crowd, presenting himself as a divine savior while secretly enjoying their blind devotion. His unpredictability terrifies even the other gods.

Chapter 35: Blood and Shadows

Kael and the rebels launch an attack on a Divine Order caravan, believing it to be transporting powerful weapons. Instead, it's a trap laid by Daziel. The battle turns into a massacre as the rebels are forced to flee, with several members gravely injured. Kael fights Daziel but is overwhelmed. Theros intervenes at the last moment, clashing with Daziel in a brief but intense exchange before retreating.

Chapter 36: Breaking Point

After their failure, the rebels argue over leadership. Erian urges them to regroup, but morale is low. Arin, Lyra, and Caius blame themselves for their own botched mission, questioning their place in the rebellion. Kael, frustrated by his own weakness, pushes himself harder, training relentlessly with Theros and Lexa.

Chapter 37: Thrakos and the Moon Weaver

Thrakos visits Vaelith, the Moon Weaver, mocking her role as a goddess of illusions. He toys with her, speaking in riddles and half-truths. When she refuses to bow to him, he forces her to, just to prove a point. His interactions with the other gods reveal his absolute dominance.

Chapter 38: Varianâ€™s Last Hunt

Varian Voss receives another bounty for Kael. He takes the job but, instead of ambushing Kael, decides to observe him from a distance. He begins questioning why the gods fear Kael so much.

Chapter 39: The Ashen Mark Evolves

During an intense training session with Theros, Kaelâ€™s Ashen Mark reacts violently to divine energy, manifesting a new ability: Weakness Perception, allowing him to instinctively see the flaws in divine beings. However, it overwhelms him, and Theros warns that unchecked power can destroy him just as easily as the gods.

Chapter 40: Dazielâ€™s Revenge

Daziel, still reeling from his loss to Kael, embarks on a personal crusade, tracking down and executing suspected rebel sympathizers. His brutality increases, making him even more dangerous. He declares that he will personally flay Kael alive and offer his body to the gods.


---

Chapters 41-50: The Orphans' Arc & Varianâ€™s Redemption

Chapter 41: The Fractured Trio

Arin, Lyra, and Caius, still shaken from their previous failure, attempt another missionâ€”this time rescuing captured rebels from an Inquisitor stronghold. Arin's careful planning clashes with Lyraâ€™s more reckless, action-driven mindset, while Caius struggles with his growing fear of battle.

Chapter 42: A Fateful Mistake

During the infiltration, Caius panics and alerts the guards. Chaos ensues, and while the trio barely escapes, the prisoners they came to save are executed. The failure breaks them apart, especially Arin, who begins doubting his intelligence for the first time.

Chapter 43: Varian's Choice

Varian Voss intervenes in a battle between Kael and another bounty hunter, finally siding with him. He declares that hunting gods is more exciting than hunting people. Kael remains wary, but Varian proves his worth by saving his life mid-battle.

Chapter 44: The Nameless Oneâ€™s Wrath

A demigod general fails Thrakos in battle. Instead of simply killing him, Thrakos forces him to kill his own family first. He smiles as he watches, then kills the general anyway.

Chapter 45: Forged in Fire

The orphans, on the verge of splitting apart, are given a brutal challenge by Theros: survive three days in the wilderness with nothing but their skills. In doing so, they rediscover their bond and develop new techniquesâ€”Arin sharpening his tactics, Lyra honing her combat, and Caius overcoming his fear.

Chapter 46-50: The War Begins

The rebels plan another major assault but fail yet again, forcing them into full retreat.

Daziel ambushes Kael, and though Kael barely survives, he is permanently scarred.

Thrakos grows bored and orders another city to be purged, playing with its inhabitants before their execution.

Varian proves himself in battle, securing his place as Kaelâ€™s new ally.

Lexa and Kael grow closer, but unresolved tensions keep them apart.



---

Chapters 51-60: The Fall of Hope

Chapter 51: Thrakosâ€™ Games

Thrakos forces two priests to duel to the death for no reason other than his amusement. Even the other gods are terrified of his growing unpredictability.

Chapter 52: Kaelâ€™s Near-Death Experience

Kael pushes himself too far in battle, activating the Ashen Markâ€™s second stage but nearly killing himself in the process. Lexa saves him, berating him for being reckless.

Chapter 53-55: The Rebelsâ€™ Last Stand

The rebels attempt one final mission to turn the tide. They fail disastrously.

Erian is gravely wounded, the rebellion is scattered, and their safe havens are destroyed.

The orphans, now battle-hardened, step up as crucial fighters.


Chapter 56: Theros vs. a Major God

Theros kills Vermithrax, God of Shadows and Illusions in an epic battle, proving his title as the strongest mortal. However, the effort leaves him severely injured. He warns Kael that even this victory means little.

Chapter 57-59: Daziel Strikes Again

Daziel captures and executes rebels, cementing himself as Kaelâ€™s most personal enemy.

Varian challenges Kael to a duel to ensure he is truly strong enough to continue fighting.


Chapter 60: The Nameless One Descends

Thrakos, growing tired of the rebellionâ€™s persistence, declares war himself. His mere presence causes the sky to darken, and his laughter echoes across the land. The final hunt for Kael begins.

2.content:
Ashen Gods (Dark Fantasy / Action / Adventure)
Premise:
In a world (The Planet Ocilia) where gods rule as tyrants, humans exist only as pawns in their divine games. The powerful live under divine protection, while the weak suffer endless oppression. But when a young warrior, Kael Ashthorne, discovers he is the last descendant of the Godslayerâ€™s Bloodline, he gains the forbidden power to kill godsâ€”something believed to be impossible.
Branded a heretic and hunted by the Divine Order, Kael embarks on a brutal journey to uncover the truth behind the godsâ€™ rule and the origins of his own power.

3.content:
Worldbuilding:


1. The Gods and Their Rule
The world is ruled by Gods. There are different tiers of Gods: Lesser Gods, Standard Gods, Major Gods and The Seven Gods of Dominion.
Lesser Gods: While still Gods and have power over humans they are not as worshipped or revered as The God of Dominion, Major or even Standard Gods and bow to the Gods that are higher than them. Lesser Gods also have less power than the Gods above them, limiting their capabilities and making them the easiest to kill.
Standard Gods: Standard Gods are normal Gods who are decently revered and worshipped. They have power over Lesser Gods. Since they are powerful deities they are a serious challenge to kill.
Major Gods: Major Gods are Highly Powerful Gods who are highly worshipped and revered. They have Power over Lesser and Standard Gods. They are levels above Standard Gods Making them nearly Impossible to kill.
The Seven Gods of Dominion: The seven Gods are the main Gods of the World who have power over everyone and everything. They have Power over Major, Standard and Lesser Gods. They are worshipped and adored by every human who is not a rebel or heretic. They are on a whole other level than Major Gods and are said to be impossible to kill.
The gods draw power from worship and fearâ€”the more followers they have, the stronger they become. However, a hidden prophecy speaks of a time when a mortal will rise to end their reign.
The Seven Gods of Dominion:
Solmara, the Sun Tyrant â€“ God of Fire and the Sun.
Vaelith, the Moon Weaver â€“ Goddess of Illusions and The Moon.
Dravon, the War Bringer â€“ God of Bloodshed and Conquest. Every battle fought in his name strengthens him.
Nyxa, the Hollow Mother â€“ Goddess of Death and Despair. The dead whisper in her wake.
Oris, the Lawkeeper â€“ God of Order and Control. He enforces absolute obedience.
Zyren, the Storm Tyrant â€“ God of Chaos and Lightning. His wrath is sudden and merciless.
The Nameless One/Thrakos (Inspired by Homelander from â€œThe Boysâ€) â€“ The God of The God. Most famous, Popular and worshipped God. He's also the strongest and it's not close.
Major Gods:
Zephyron, God of Winds and Freedom
Domain: Air, Freedom, Travel
Appearance: A tall, ethereal figure with flowing robes that mimic the colors of the sky. His hair appears like wisps of cloud, and his eyes shimmer like the sun reflecting on water.
Background: Zephyron is revered by travelers and wanderers, offering them safe passage through storms and rough terrains. He embodies the spirit of adventure and liberation, encouraging mortals to pursue their dreams without restraint.
Morrigan, Goddess of Fate and War
Domain: Fate, War, Darkness
Appearance: A striking woman clad in dark armor, with raven-black hair and eyes that glow like embers. She often appears with a crow perched on her shoulder.
Background: Morrigan is a fierce warrior goddess who influences the tides of battle and the fates of individuals. Mortals invoke her name for courage in conflict, and she is known to decide the fates of fallen heroes.
Therion, God of Beasts and Wilderness
Domain: Nature, Animals, Survival
Appearance: A muscular figure with the features of a stag, adorned with leaves and vines. His hands are clawed, and he can transform into various animals.
Background: Therion is the protector of the natural world, ensuring the balance between civilization and the wilderness. He often guides lost souls through the forests and teaches them the ways of survival.
Aeloria, Goddess of Love and Beauty
Domain: Love, Beauty, Healing
Appearance: A radiant figure with long, flowing hair that sparkles like starlight. She wears gowns made of petals and embodies every aspect of beauty, compassion, and affection.
Background: Aeloria brings together souls destined to love and guides them through the complexities of relationships. She also heals emotional wounds and inspires artists and romantics alike.
Pyros, God of Fire and Destruction
Domain: Fire, Destruction, Passion
Appearance: A towering figure wreathed in flames, with a fiery beard and glowing red eyes. His presence is both mesmerizing and terrifying.
Background: Pyros represents the duality of fireâ€”both destructive and transformative. He is worshiped by those who harness fire for creation, as well as those who seek vengeance through its power.
Selene, Goddess of the Moon and Secrets
Domain: Moon, Night, Knowledge
Appearance: A graceful figure bathed in silvery light, with a crescent moon upon her forehead and a gown that flows like liquid silver.
Background: Selene guards the secrets of the universe, revealing hidden truths to those who seek her guidance at night. She oversees the cycles of life and death and is often associated with dreams and intuition.
Thalassia, Goddess of the Sea and Storms
Domain: Oceans, Storms, Travel
Appearance: A majestic woman with flowing blue hair and a dress made of waves. She wields a trident, and her eyes are like whirlpools.
Background: Thalassia governs the vast waters and is both a nurturer and a destroyer of sailors. Those who venture into her realm must pay homage for safe passage, while her tempests remind all of her unfathomable power.
Kronyx, God of Time and Change
Domain: Time, Destiny, Transformation
Appearance: An enigmatic figure who appears older and younger simultaneously, with a flowing robe adorned with celestial patterns and an hourglass in his hand.
Background: Kronyx oversees the fabric of reality and the passage of time. Mortals seek his wisdom during pivotal moments, hoping to understand their place in the grand tapestry of existence.
Vermithrax, God of Shadows and Illusions
Domain: Shadows, Illusions, Trickery
Appearance: A cloaked figure, almost featureless but with a smirk appearing when he chooses, surrounded by swirling shadows and flickering lights.
Background: Vermithrax revels in unpredictability and mischief. He is invoked by those who seek to deceive or escape detection and teaches that not everything is as it seems.
Elaris, Goddess of Knowledge and Wisdom
Domain: Knowledge, Wisdom, Enlightenment
Appearance: A wise woman with flowing white hair and eyes like deep pools of knowledge. She carries an ornate book and a quill, adorned in robes covered in celestial symbols.
Background: Elaris embodies the pursuit of knowledge and understanding. Scholars, seekers, and inquisitive minds look to her for enlightenment and guidance in their quests for truth. She encourages the sharing of knowledge among mortals.
Standard Gods:
Adara, Goddess of Harvest
Domain: Agriculture, Fertility, Abundance
Appearance: A cheerful woman with sun-kissed skin, wearing a dress made of grains and flowers. She carries a cornucopia overflowing with produce.
Background: Adara blesses farmers with bountiful harvests and is worshiped during planting and harvest festivals.
Brom, God of Smithing
Domain: Crafts, Metalwork, Labor
Appearance: A muscular man with soot on his face and a leather apron, holding a hammer and anvil.
Background: Brom inspires artisans and laborers, granting them strength and skill in their crafts. He is often invoked before beginning a new project.
Celestra, Goddess of Stars
Domain: Astronomy, Guidance, Night
Appearance: A serene figure adorned with a gown of stars, her hair flowing like the night sky.
Background: Celestra guides travelers by the stars and is worshiped by navigators and dreamers alike.
Darin, God of Music
Domain: Art, Music, Celebration
Appearance: A spirited man with flowing hair, playing a lyre surrounded by dancing lights.
Background: Darin inspires musicians and brings joy to celebrations, fostering community through music and dance.
Elara, Goddess of Healing
Domain: Health, Healing, Compassion
Appearance: A gentle woman with soft features, dressed in white robes, holding a staff with a crystal at its tip.
Background: Elara is sought after by the sick and injured, and her teachings emphasize kindness and care for one another.
Fenn, God of the Forest
Domain: Nature, Wildlife, Exploration
Appearance: A rugged figure with leaves and vines intertwined in his hair and clothing, holding a wooden staff.
Background: Fenn protects the forests and all its inhabitants. Wanderers and hunters honor him for guidance and protection.
Galdor, God of Protection
Domain: Safety, Guardianship, Fortitude
Appearance: A strong, armored figure with a shield emblazoned with a lion, radiating a protective aura.
Background: Galdor watches over communities and individuals, granting courage and strength to those in need.
Hestia, Goddess of Home
Domain: Hearth, Family, Community
Appearance: A warm woman with a glowing smile, dressed in simple garments, holding a flame.
Background: Hestia embodies the spirit of the home and is honored during family gatherings and celebrations.
Iris, Goddess of the Rainbow
Domain: Hope, Transformation, Beauty
Appearance: A vibrant figure surrounded by a spectrum of colors, with a cloak that sparkles like rainbows.
Background: Iris is a symbol of hope and renewal, often invoked during times of change or adversity.
Jorin, God of Commerce
Domain: Trade, Wealth, Negotiation
Appearance: A sharp-dressed figure with a calculating smile, holding a scale and a ledger.
Background: Jorin oversees fair trade and successful negotiations, and merchants often pray to him before business dealings.
Kira, Goddess of Wisdom
Domain: Knowledge, Insight, Learning
Appearance: A wise woman with glasses perched on her nose, surrounded by scrolls and books.
Background: Kira encourages the pursuit of education and truth, uplifting scholars and seekers of knowledge.
Lyra, Goddess of Dreams
Domain: Dreams, Imagination, Night
Appearance: A dreamy figure with stars in her hair and a gown of flowing mist, often appearing with a gentle smile.
Background: Lyra guides souls through the realm of dreams and is worshiped for protection against nightmares.
Milo, God of the Sea
Domain: Water, Navigation, Emotions
Appearance: A rugged figure with waves crashing around him, dressed in blue and green hues, holding a trident.
Background: Milo governs the oceans and is often called upon by sailors to ensure safe journeys and calm waters.
Nara, Goddess of Seasons
Domain: Change, Nature Cycles, Harmony
Appearance: A figure with a gown that shifts colors with the seasonsâ€”green for spring, gold for summer, red for autumn, and white for winter.
Background: Nara oversees the cycles of nature, reminding mortals to embrace change and the passage of time.
Oren, God of Fire
Domain: Fire, Passion, Creativity
Appearance: A lively figure with flickering red and orange flames around him, dressed in fiery colors.
Background: Oren fuels creativity and passion, often called upon by artists and creators when beginning their work.
Paxia, Goddess of Peace
Domain: Tranquility, Harmony, Compassion
Appearance: A serene woman draped in soft pastel colors, often surrounded by peaceful animals and a gentle breeze.
Background: Paxia promotes peace and resolution in conflicts, encouraging communities to embrace love and understanding.
Quillan, God of Adventure
Domain: Exploration, Courage, Journey
Appearance: A dashing figure dressed for travel, with a backpack and a map, radiant with energy and excitement.
Background: Quillan inspires adventurous spirits, urging them to explore the world and seek out new experiences.
Lesser Gods:
Azura, Goddess of Morning Dew
Domain: Agriculture, Moisture, Renewal
Appearance: A delicate woman with hair as pale as mist, surrounded by gentle dew drops.
Background: Azura helps plants grow by bringing moisture to the earth.
Bram, God of Small Caves
Domain: Exploration, Shelter, Protection
Appearance: A sturdy man with a beard, often seen in small caves, holding a pickaxe.
Background: Bram provides shelter and protection to those who seek refuge in the earth.
Calantha, Goddess of Wildflowers
Domain: Nature, Beauty, Whimsy
Appearance: A playful woman with hair as colorful as the flowers she loves, surrounded by blooming wildflowers.
Background: Calantha brings joy to the natural world through her beautiful, fleeting creations.
Dakon, God of Minor Wounds
Domain: Health, Pain, Recovery
Appearance: A compassionate man with a gentle touch, often seen in the company of minor injuries and ailments.
Background: Dakon eases minor pain and helps the injured recover, reminding mortals that even small hurts can have great importance.
Eira, Goddess of Frost
Domain: Winter, Cold, Preservation
Appearance: A serene woman with hair as white as snow, often surrounded by frost and icicles.
Background: Eira protects food from spoilage and keeps the earth stable during the harshest of winters.
Fen, God of Marshy Waters
Domain: Water, Wetlands, Adaptation
Appearance: A flexible figure with skin like the reeds that thrive in the marshes, often seen in murky waters.
Background: Fen adapts to the ever-changing tides and helps those who live in harmony with the wetlands.
Gwyn, Goddess of Twilight
Domain: Transitions, Twilight, Mystery
Appearance: A quiet woman with hair as dark as the twilight sky, often surrounded by shadows and mist.
Background: Gwyn eases the transition from one time of day to another and keeps secrets hidden from those who seek them.
Hawk, God of Short-Range Sight
Domain: Perception, Clarity, Awareness
Appearance: A vigilant bird with eyes sharp as hawks, often seen perched at the edge of a clearing.
Background: Hawk enhances mortal perception, granting the ability to spot hidden dangers or find lost paths.
Ithari, Goddess of Flickering Embers
Domain: Fire, Light, Resilience
Appearance: A small woman with hair that crackles like sparks, often holding a small torch.
Background: Ithari keeps embers burning, providing hope in dark times and reminding mortals of the resilience of fire.
Jax, God of Minor Quakes
Domain: Earth, Balance, Resilience
Appearance: A sturdy man with hair as earthy as the ground, often seen in the midst of minor tremors.
Background: Jax maintains balance in the earth, reminding mortals of the importance of adaptability and resilience.
Kairos, God of Fleeting Moments
Domain: Transience, Opportunity, Decision
Appearance: A fluid figure with hair as windblown as the leaves of autumn, often seen in the midst of changing circumstances.
Background: Kairos reminds mortals to seize opportunities and make swift decisions, as moments lost can never be regained.
Lila, Goddess of Small Fruits
Domain: Agriculture, Abundance, Nourishment
Appearance: A vibrant woman with hair as colorful as the fruits she loves, often surrounded by small, ripe fruits.
Background: Lila provides nourishment to mortals through the bounty of small fruits and reminds them of the importance of gratitude.
Mael, God of Coastal Erosion
Domain: Water, Change, Adaptation
Appearance: A fluid figure with skin as smooth as the tides, often seen in the midst of shifting coastlines.
Background: Mael helps mortals adapt to the ever-changing coastline, reminding them of the importance of resilience and flexibility.
Niam, Goddess of Soft Rains
Domain: Water, Refreshment, Calm
Appearance: A soothing woman with hair as gentle as a summer breeze, often seen in the midst of soft, refreshing rains.
Background: Niam brings calm and renewal through her gentle rains, soothing the parched earth and reviving the spirits of mortals.
Onyx, Goddess of Shadows in Daylight
Domain: Night, Hiding, Safety
Appearance: A mysterious woman with hair as dark as the shadows, often seen hiding in plain sight during daylight hours.
Background: Onyx safeguards secrets and provides shelter from the harsh light of day.
Phyllis, Goddess of Young Trees
Domain: Nature, Growth, Youth
Appearance: A sprightly woman with hair as green as the leaves of young trees, often seen in the midst of forests.
Background: Phyllis guides young trees in their growth, reminding mortals of the importance of nurturing and care.
Quintus, God of Quiet Conversations
Domain: Communication, Understanding, Peace
Appearance: A calm man with a gentle smile, often seen in the company of quiet conversations.
Background: Quintus fosters understanding and peaceful resolution through quiet, respectful communication.
Ragna, Goddess of Frosty Mornings
Domain: Winter, Cold, Renewal
Appearance: A serene woman with hair as frosty as the mornings, often seen in the midst of winter's chill.
Background: Ragna brings renewal and clarity through her frosty touch, reviving the spirits of mortals and reminding them of the importance of resilience.
Sana, Goddess of Gentle Breezes
Domain: Air, Comfort, Calm
Appearance: A soothing woman with hair as soft as the wind, often seen in the midst of gentle breezes.
Background: Sana brings comfort and peace through her gentle breezes, soothing the troubled minds of mortals.
Tanith, Goddess of Forgotten Memories
Domain: Memory, Nostalgia, Loss
Appearance: A mysterious woman with hair that holds the whispers of the past, often seen in the company of forgotten memories.
Background: Tanith safeguards forgotten memories and nostalgic longing, reminding mortals of the importance of preserving the past.
Uma, Goddess of Quiet Lakes
Domain: Water, Serenity, Reflection
Appearance: A peaceful woman with hair as calm as the lakes she loves, often seen in the midst of quiet waters.
Background: Uma provides serenity and reflection, reminding mortals of the importance of introspection and calm contemplation.
Vega, Goddess of Morning Dewdrops
Domain: Agriculture, Renewal, Freshness
Appearance: A delicate woman with hair as pale as the morning dew, often seen in the company of dew drops.
Background: Vega brings renewal and freshness through her gentle morning dew, nourishing crops and reviving the spirits of mortals.
Wynd, God of Minor Storms
Domain: Weather, Turbulence, Resilience
Appearance: A rugged man with hair as turbulent as minor storms, often seen in the midst of shifting weather patterns.
Background: Wynd tests the resilience of mortals through minor storms and turbulence, reminding them of the importance of adaptability.




2. The Divine Order
A militaristic theocracy that enforces the godsâ€™ rule. Its elite warriors, the Seraphim Knights are granted divine powers in exchange for absolute loyalty. Their leader, High Inquisitor Daziel, is a fanatic who believes killing the Godslayer is his sacred duty. Demi-Gods also work to enforce divine rule.




3. Bounty systems
The currency in Ocilia is Ocelis(âš·). Bounty Hunters who killed Godslayers have made the most money. Deicide is the highest crime in Ocilia which puts the highest bounty on the Godslayerâ€™s head.
Bounty for the each kill of a Lesser God:âš·250,000,000,000
Bounty for each kill of a Standard God:âš·1,000,000,000,000
Bounty for each kill of a Major God:âš·10,000,000,000,000
Bounty for each kill of One of The Seven Gods of Dominion:âš·25,000,000,000,000




4. Forging Godslaying weapons
The Aetherstone is a mythical gem forged in the heart of a dying star, combining cosmic energy with unyielding strength. Its surface shimmers with hues of deep indigo and vibrant violet, appearing to shift and pulse with an otherworldly light. When held, it radiates an aura of power that can be felt by Gods and Demi-Gods. It's the only material that can be used against the Gods and is used for Godslaying weapons.

5.content:
Kael Ashthorne:
Role: Protagonist, Godslayer
Species: Human
Age: 16 
Appearance: 5â€™9, agile and speedy, Fair skin, reddish brown hair with medium-long length, gray eyes, wears Godslaying gear 
Traits: Vengeful, passionate, loving, caring, selfless, hotheaded, strong sense of justice, loves fighting, conflicted about his desire for revenge versus his developing powers.
Growth: Learns to harness his powers while grappling with the pain of loss and his growing notoriety.
Weapon: Ebonfang â€“ The Blade That Drinks Divinity
Appearance: A jagged, made of Aetherstone, glowing like molten veins.
Ability: Drains divine energy upon striking a god, weakening them with each hit.
Ultimate Effect: If Ebonfang kills a god, it stores a fragment of their power, allowing Kael to unleash a single, devastating attack infused with their essence before the energy fades.

6.content:
Theros Nightvale (Inspired by Kakashi Hatake and Levi Ackerman from â€œNarutoâ€ and â€œAttack on Titan)â€:
Role: Mentor Figure
Species: Human
Age: 28
Appearance: A tall agile man (6'2), he has multi-colored hair (brown on the sides and back, white on the top) he wears the best quality Godslaying gear.
Traits: Stoic, experienced, mysterious, sarcastic, dry humor, extremely skilled, calm, reserved, known and feared worldwide.
Backstory: Tied to The Nameless One through a past encounter, revealing powerful insights about power and sacrifice.
Weapon: Tyrantâ€™s Fall â€“ The Hammer That Breaks Divinity
Appearance: A massive Aetherstone warhammer, its head shaped like a crumbling temple.
Ability: Shatters divine constructs, including weapons, shields, and protective wards.
Ultimate Effect: A single full-power strike can crack the very foundation of a godâ€™s existence, making them vulnerable to mortal attacks.
Introduced: Chapter 2

7.content:
The Nameless One/Thrakos (Inspired by Homelander from â€œThe Boysâ€):
Role: Main Antagonist, All-Powerful God
Species: Deity
Age: 3147
Traits: Narcissistic, dominant, sadistic, entitled, petty, competitive, loves fighting, sees himself as an essential force.
Motivation: Desires chaos and power; sees humans as bugs compared to Gods. Is feared by every being in the World and everyone but the rebels obey him
Introduced: Mentioned from Chapter 1-29 as the Nameless one, invoking fear every time he's mentioned. He is properly introduced at the end of chapter 30

8.content:
Lexa Vael:
Role: Love Interest
Species: Demi-God
Age: 17
Appearance: She's a petite girl (5â€™4) with medium long blue hair and with fiery golden yellow eyes. She wears a white leather armor and carries two divine daggers. 
Traits: Determined, resourceful, blunt, fiery, short-tempered, brave.
Background: Love-hate relationship with Kael, constantly bickering.She understands his struggle better than anyoneâ€”being caught between mortality and divinity She challenges him to get stronger rather than trying to calm him down. She's a Demi-God warrior who fights against the Gods after getting disowned by her father (Dravon, the War Bringer â€“ God of Bloodshed and Conquest) for having mortal blood.
